ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a typical day that demonstrates why itâs unclear to me how Terri Francis teaches a class at Yale:When we sat down at the second to last class of the entire semester she announced, âHm, I havenât actually given much thought to what weâre going to do todayâ¦but I guess weâre here! Soâ¦âAfter treating us to musings on whether avant-garde can survive, musings separate from any reading that I havenât looked since the second week of class because it never came up in discussions, Francis decides to open up the powerpoint she showed us during shopping period that features random samples of paintings from the last four hundred years. She settles on Courbetâs âThe Stone Breakersâ and says, âYeah, so this is people breaking stone...â more pausing. âI donât know, what do you think of this?â âWhat do you know about it?â After six seconds of silence one student finally says, âI mean itâs been a while, since high school, but I think itâs about...â We then have a meandering discussion over twenty minutes about whether still life paintings are more real than portraits of stone breakers.Then Francis shares a five minute anecdote about iPhones.Ten minutes on whether film is different from other art forms. Francis says something like, âItâs not pretty to be a starving artist.âEventually we drained through an hour and fifty minutes, and it was time to leave.This class also features:--weekly screenings Francis doesnât come to and that we never talk about again--a class when we stare at scrapbooks in the Beinecke for an hour and fifty minutes--a class when we walk around sculptures on Yaleâs campusI guess what Iâm saying is--if you thought you could never do six classes, hereâs your chance.

It can be difficult to stay focused the entire period in the morning, but this is a laid-back class that really depends upon you to bring your passion for cinema into the conversation. If you don't, you may very well be bored. If you do, you will find it much more worthwhile.
Take it if you're gonna watch the movies - it's a good selection, and many of them are hard to come by otherwise... If you're motivated to learn about this stuff on your own, it's worth it....
Yes, if you have an interest in the avant garde

It's a course on experimental film (really avant-garde stuff) with accompanying readings. Take the course if you want to watch super artsy films that would be in a gallery setting. Don't expect narrative or contentâalmost all the films are literally just formal elements, like paintings on screen. I would recommend it if you really care about this type of film, otherwise the discussion can be boring.
Really chill class focusing on the discussion of films that are really weird, cool, and sometimes disturbing. Take if it sounds interesting to you.

Avant-garde is a really cool class. I love art house/international/independent movies so I thought I'd like this class. It took me a while to get used to the craziness/boringness of some of the films, but after a while everything just sort of clicks.Since a lot of this stuff was done during the mid 20th century, and since it was done purely for the sake of art, you get to see what life was really like before you were born. In some ways, I feel like I learned more about human nature and history from this class than from any others.This is a fun class. I didn't do a single reading. It might be good as a fifth class or credit d. although getting an A isn't too difficult.
